awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Autonomous Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) for surface deformation monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable the global autonomous detection of surface deformation. Measuring Earth surface deformation is fundamental to detect and analyze surface and subsurface changes due to anthropogenic activity, with a myriad of industrial applications that includes the monitoring of oil and gas extraction fields and storage reservoirs, mining operations, carbon dioxide sequestration, and/or infrastructure integrity. Illustrating the economic and social impact of its uses, the market for analyzing Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) data is expected to double within 5 years. Beyond the dramatic economic growth of InSAR, its far-ranging applications have broad social and scientific impacts, in particular related to natural hazards and climate change.  Advances in InSAR processing and improved signal-to-noise ratios will translate into improved monitoring of earthquake activity, landslides, water supplies, deforestation, floods, ice sheets, etc.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims at tackling the lack of automation in InSAR processing and improving detection thresholds in InSAR time series analysis. While the technique can potentially measure millimeter-scale changes in deformation over periods of days to years, atmospheric effects can wreak havoc on repeat-pass InSAR interpretation by introducing errors that may mask small surface deformations. These effects, which are fundamentally due to pressure, temperature and relative humidity variations in the troposphere, can lead to errors that are larger than most of the deformation signals of interest. Current algorithms are not suited for automated, large-scale monitoring without a priori data because they require time-consuming manual intervention, and the final product requires exhaustive expert interpretation. Through the development of machine learning and artificial intelligence methods this project aims at: (i) further automating and accelerating the processing of InSAR time series, via the automation of some key sections of the processing pipeline that still rely on extensive and costly human intervention; and (ii) developing a new methodology to generate InSAR time series, that is robust to noise and allows for a finer temporal and spatial resolution compared to the state-of-the-art.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
InSAR is a powerful tool to detect and analyze surface and subsurface changes due to natural or anthropogenic activity, with a myriad of applications that includes the monitoring of oil and gas extraction fields and storage reservoirs, mining operations, infrastructure integrity, CO2 sequestration, water supplies, natural hazards (earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides), etc.

Current algorithms require time-consuming manual intervention and are not suited for automated, large scale monitoring, explaining why a major fraction of InSAR data already produced by existing satellite constellations is never analyzed.


Our project has aimed at drastically lowering the cost of InSAR analysis by alleviating the need for human labor and expertise during both the processing chain and the analysis of final products. InSAR data processing is an intricate but mature technology, that aims at reconstructing a deformation time series from a set of interferogram pairs. The main codes used by the community to process SAR images are the ISCE (InSAR Scientific Computing Environment), GMTSAR, and GAMMA (commercial) packages. Parts of these libraries have been modified to run on GPU, but overall the processing chains remain very slow, and often (depending on the desired accuracy) relies on human intervention at some steps (mostly unwrapping).

The goal of this phase I project has been to develop an InSAR automation suite, and demonstrate its use for monitoring on historical data. Our ultimate goal is to develop a fully automatic end-to-end InSAR pipeline ready for scalability. The novelty is that most steps of the pipeline will take advantage of state-of-the-art data science tools including machine learning and optimal transport, two innovations that will allow to speed up and improve the quality of the processing of satellite imagery.

To that end, the outcomes of the project have been the following:

The milestones for the project, aiming at accelerating and automatizing the InSAR processing chain, are the following:

  •     We implemented one of the slowest components (image registration) of the classic InSAR processing chain on GPU, yielding a x16 speedup.

  •      We developed deep learning models to correct for unwrapping errors, one of the major current bottlenecks of the InSAR processing chain, as it typically involves the intervention of a human analyst. Our unwrapping error detector achieves a 0.999 area under the receiver-operator curve, and can therefore replace human verification of the unwrapping step.

  •     We developed Wasserstein barycenter approaches for time series reconstruction, that improves the quality of the output time series compared to existing approaches such as the Small Baseline Subset (SBAS) by 25% (as measured by reconstruction error).

  •     We applied our algorithms on real InSAR data over California, demonstrating their scalability and automation.










Last Modified: 10/19/2024
Modified by: Claudia Hulbert

Images (1 of )
  • Detecting unwrapping errors by deep learning. Example of using deep learning to detect unwrapping errors. Synthetic data from a test set, not used during the training of our deep learning model. First column: wrapped interferogram. Second column: unwrapped interferogram. Third column: pixels where
    Geolabe
    Copyrighted
    Claudia Hulbert
    Unwrapping error detection
  • Registration comparison of subswath SW1, between one of the main InSAR libraries (GMTSAR) and our algorithm. Our GPU implementation achieves a speedup of 16, with relative errors of the order of 10^-11.
    Geolabe
    Copyrighted
    Claudia Hulbert
    Registration comparison of subswath SW1, between one of the main InSAR libraries (GMTSAR) and our algorithm.

To that end, the outcomes of the project have been the following:


The milestones for the project, aiming at accelerating and automatizing the InSAR processing chain, are the following:




 We implemented 	one of the slowest components (image registration) of the classic 	InSAR processing chain on GPU, yielding a x16 speedup.




 We 	developed deep learning models to correct for unwrapping errors, one 	of the major current bottlenecks of the InSAR processing chain, as 	it typically involves the intervention of a human analyst. Our 	unwrapping error detector achieves a 0.999 area under the 	receiver-operator curve, and can therefore replace human 	verification of the unwrapping step.

 We applied our algorithms on real InSAR 	data over California, demonstrating their scalability and 	automation.
